title.title: Letter from Superintendent Z. A. Philips to Mississippi Governor Adelbert Ames; August 25, 1869

msIdentifier.collection: Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, Main Collection

note.p: Adelbert Ames served as a governor and U.S. senator of Mississippi during the Reconstruction era. He was born in East Thomaston (modern-day Rockland), Maine, in 1835. As a boy, Ames spent time working on various merchant vessels, receiving training in seamanship. He entered the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1856, graduating in May 1861, at the start of the Civil War. Commissioned as a second lieutenant, the young Ames was promoted to first lieutenant barely over a week later and served with the 5th U.S. Artillery during the battle of First Bull Run at Manassas, Virginia, on July 21, 1861. Despite being wounded in the leg, Ames stayed by his cannons. His actions at Bull Run led him to receive the brevet (honorary) rank of major and, in 1893 (more than thirty years later), the Medal of Honor.

Ames recovered from his wound and returned to the front lines in 1862, serving with distinction as an artillery officer during the Peninsula Campaign near Richmond. Seeking better promotion potential, Ames sought an infantry command. Through those efforts, in August 1862, he received command of the 20th Maine Infantry Regiment, and led that unit in combat during the Battle of Fredericksburg in December 1862. In May 1863, he volunteered to serve as a staff officer for Major General George G. Meade, which helped him achieve the rank of brigadier general that month. With this promotion, Ames left the 20th Maine to his second-in-command, Lieutenant Colonel Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain, who gained great fame commanding the regiment at Little Round Top during the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863. Ames’ own performance at Gettysburg was highly praised, as his division successfully defended the Union position at Cemetery Hill.

After Gettysburg, Ames’ division was transferred to the Department of the South. Over the next two years, he commanded Union troops during campaigns in Florida, South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia. He received a brevet promotion to major general for his actions at Fort Fisher, North Carolina, in March 1865.

After the Civil War, Ames became involved in federal Reconstruction efforts. In 1868, he was appointed the provisional governor of Mississippi. Ames proved sympathetic to the plight of African Americans in the south. He sought to protect Black civil rights and appointed Mississippi’s first African American public officials. In 1870, after Mississippi was readmitted into the Union, Ames ran for U.S. senator for the state as a Republican and won. He served in that capacity from February 1870 to January 1874, achieving the reputation as a strong public speaker. While serving as a senator in Washington, D.C., Ames met and married Blanche Butler, daughter of Union general Benjamin F. Butler, under whom Ames had served during the war. Ames and his wife had six children over the course of their marriage.

In 1873, Ames ran for governor of Mississippi. His chief rival was James L. Alcorn, a former Confederate general who had been a Whig before the Civil War and joined the Republican Party afterwards. Ames won the election and worked diligently to improve Mississippi’s financial and social situation. In 1874, Democrats in Mississippi coordinated a campaign of violence against African Americans and white Republicans in the state, to secure political control in Mississippi. Unable to militarily suppress the white supremacist terror campaign, Ames signed a truce with Democratic leaders in Mississippi to reduce the violence and allow a peaceful election. Groups of white supremacists abandoned the truce and resumed their intimidation tactics against Republicans and Black Mississippians during the following elections, leading to a surge of Democratic politicians taking office.

In 1876, the conservative Democrat majority in the Mississippi legislature tried to impeach Ames and many other Republican officials with trumped up charges of corruption. Despite a strong political force against him, Ames’ critics were unable to provide any evidence of impropriety. Nevertheless, because impeachment was politically driven, Ames could see that his future as governor was over and any effort on his part to legally defend himself would be personally and financially taxing. He and his attorneys reached an agreement with Democratic leaders to resign his office in exchange for dropping the legal charges. On March 29, 1876, after Democrats cancelled their legal proceedings, Ames vacated his position.

Ames left Mississippi and went into business in Minnesota with his father and brother. A short time later, he relocated to New York City and then Massachusetts, overseeing mills and various business interests. When the Spanish-American War erupted in 1898, Ames volunteered for service and was appointed brigadier general of volunteers. Although over sixty years old, Ames joined the field campaign in Cuba and performed well.
Ames resumed his business ventures in the early twentieth century. He lived until 1933, dying at age 97. He is buried in Lowell, Massachusetts.
Adelbert Ames belonged to the following social groups:
Z. A. Phillips was a businessman, entrepreneur, and state official in Mississippi in the nineteenth century.

Part owner of the Southern Agricultural Implement Factory, an agricultural machinery company, in Jackson, Mississippi, by 1860, Phillips was commissioned as a salt agent by the state government during the Civil War to acquire large quantities of the mineral for public and private use.

Shortly after the war, he returned to his business pursuits in Jackson, operating the Pearl River Manufacturing Company with partner Joshua Green. Philips also pursued an appointment as superintendent of the Mississippi penitentiary, acquiring that office by 1870. He mixed his state office with business, instituting Mississippi's convict leasing system and advertising the sale of manufactured goods from the penitentiary. Phillips died in 1873.

(Semi-Weekly Mississippian, Jackson, MS, June 29, 1860; Timothy B. Smith, Mississippi in the Civil War: The Home Front, 107; The Daily Mississippian, Jackson, MS, July 31, 1864; Daily Mississippi clarion and Standard, Jackson, MS, May 9, 1866; The Semi-Weekly Clarion, Jackson, MS, December 30, 1870)
Z. A. Phillips belonged to the following social groups:
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)

Located in east-central Mississippi, Lauderdale County was established on December 23, 1833 from Rankin and Wayne counties. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: When the 13th Amendment abolished slavery, it failed to abolish involuntary servitude. The amendment included a loophole banning involuntary servitude "except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted" (Library of Congress). White southerners in the post-emancipation South, concerned about both the availability of labor and the freedom of African Americans, manipulated this clause and turned to convict leasing to entrench long standing racial hierarchies.

Immediately after the war, many states passed "Black Codes" or laws severely limiting African Americans' rights. Under these codes and other similar laws passed in the decades following the Civil War, African Americans could be arrested for any number of petty crimes, including vagrancy (functionally construed to mean any act of social mobility not approved by a white person) or theft (in Mississippi a felony if exceeding $10 worth of goods). Widespread racism and stereotypes about Black criminality led to a dramatic expansion in the population of imprisoned individuals and an overwhelming number of African Americans within that population. Many states leased those convicted persons to private companies or individuals for their labor, and in certain cases lessees had been the pre-emancipation enslaver of the leased.

Laborers worked in a variety of settings including shipbuilding and timber cutting, yet the most prominent form in states like Mississippi remained large-scale agricultural work. The convict lease system was incredibly dangerous and difficult for those who lived through it, as leased persons faced unsafe working conditions, inadequate living conditions, abuse from lessees, and grueling work schedules. Given these circumstances, the ready availability of imprisoned laborers, and the callousness of lessees and state officials, the mortality rate among convict laborers was incredibly high.

Certain states ceased leasing imprisoned persons to individuals or private companies in the late nineteenth century, only to continue using that labor on state-funded infrastructure projects like road or highway construction until, in some cases, World War II. Southern individuals and states thereby continued to increase their wealth through the coerced labor of African Americans while perpetuating anti-Black racism and laying the foundations of the modern prison-industrial complex (Library of Congress; Mississippi Encyclopedia).

In the wake of the Civil War, many states turned to convict leasing to bolster infrastructural repair and to maintain long standing racial hierarchies. Like many other southern states, Mississippi instituted a convict leasing program, and in 1876 the state passed the Leasing Act (commonly known as the “Pig Law”), which sentenced anyone who stole property valued at $10 or greater up to five years in prison and quadrupled the prison population, with Black prisoners comprising approximately 85% of inmates. The state most frequently leased convicted persons to individuals, primarily to perform agricultural work on cotton farms.

However, the state also leased incarcerated persons to private companies, such as the Gulf & Ship Island Railroad Company, and companies subjected convict-laborers to excruciating working conditions with little shelter, sustenance, or medical care. While companies and private individuals leased enslaved workers during the antebellum era, enslavers expected “their human chattel to be returned alive and in good working condition” (Sturkey, Hattiesburg). However, this expectation was virtually nonexistent in postwar convict leasing programs. The death toll therefore grew to staggering heights. In response, Mississippi cancelled Gulf & Ship Island’s contract in December 1888 and ceased leasing convicts to private companies in 1890. However, the state and individual counties and towns continued to use convict labor for public works projects and at the state’s penitentiary at Parchman plantation well into the twentieth century (Mississippi Encyclopedia).

Like many slaveholding states of the former Confederacy, Mississippi operated a convict leasing system between the 1860s–1900s. Under convict leasing systems, states leased imprisoned people to perform unfree labor for companies and individuals in exchange for a fee. State and county laws (such as "Pig Laws" and vagrancy laws) and racially selective prosecutions funneled large, overrepresented populations of African Americans into their prison institutions. Therefore, Mississippi's convict leasing system replaced the state's former system of race-based chattel slavery and laborers encountered harsh conditions, violent punishments, and high death tolls. Public outcry over these conditions, especially following the Gulf & Ship Island Railroad Company's convict leasing practices, forced Mississippi to abolish its convict leasing program in 1890, becoming the first state to do so. County governments, however, continued to operate convict leasing arrangements using chain gangs until the 1900s. In 1904 Mississippi opened Parchman Prison on a cotton plantation in the Mississippi Delta and consolidated much of its convict labor there. (Mississippi Encyclopedia)
Engaging in "illegal activities." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of taking something that does not belong to you, but not in a way that involves force or the threat of force." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Having officially been found guilty of a crime in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of putting someone in prison or the condition of being kept in prison." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"In law, a sentence is the punishment for a crime ordered by a trial court after conviction in a criminal procedure, normally at the conclusion of a trial. A sentence may consist of imprisonment, a fine, or other sanctions." (Wikipedia)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where criminals are kept as a punishment for their crimes or while waiting for trials." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"Mississippi State Penitentiary, also known as Parchman Farm, is a maximum-security prison farm located in unincorporated Sunflower County, Mississippi, in the Mississippi Delta region. Occupying about 28 square miles (73 km2) of land, Parchman is the only maximum security prison for men in the state of Mississippi, and is the state's oldest prison." (Wikipedia)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Social Identifiers -- Family Structures
Social Identifiers -- Health

gloss.p: Pregnancy is defined by the Cambridge Dictionary as "the state of a female with a baby developing inside the womb" (Cambridge Dictionary). Both the philosophies and practices surrounding female pregnancy developed greatly in the nineteenth century United States. The average white woman married at roughly the age of twenty and had an average of seven children over the course of a lifetime.

Families in the early republic valued childbearing for numerous reasons, including having more hands to help sustain the family and produce goods in a time in which many households were self-sufficient. Ideologically, the concept of "republican motherhood" signified that women's role in the nation was to produce and rear children that would become informed and honorable citizens.

However, enslaved women's reproductive capacities were perceived by white enslavers strictly for economic reasons. After the close of the Atlantic slave trade in 1807, enslaved women were raped by their enslavers or forced to "breed" with enslaved men to produce children and thus increase their enslavers' wealth. Women, Black or white, faced numerous health risks during pregnancy and birth, as the mortality rate remained high for all people but particularly birthing mothers due to inadequate medical knowledge and care.

The vast majority of women gave birth surrounded by female midwives and family members. Though some elite white women turned to male physicians to aid in birth, this practice was limited to those who could both afford to pay for a male physician and those who valued university education, remaining largely unpopular until the twentieth century. The rising industrialism of the mid-century U. S., however, slowed birth rates, and the average size of families dropped from seven children to roughly five, as families relied less on making goods in the household and invested more heavily in the advancement of individual children as means of escaping poverty. By mid-century, the knowledge, availability, and use of contraceptives and abortive measures also increased dramatically for women seeking to prevent or terminate pregnancies.

In a nation in which their reproduction often offered the only means of political and civic activity, many women, Black and white, indeed saw contraception and abortion as not only a way of aligning themselves with their own cultural, social, and personal values and desires, but also as an avenue of independent political action and bodily autonomy. The consequent rise in abortions thus led to a reactionary backlash from many white male physicians, politicians, and religious leaders, fearing both the impact of abortion on the nation (due to their ideas of "republican motherhood") and, for enslavers, on their fortunes. The late-nineteenth century therefore saw an increase in anti-abortion laws and restrictions on women's reproductive rights at the same time methods of controlling reproduction expanded. Therefore, as one scholar argues, in the United States, "the nineteenth century was an era of both reproductive revolution and reproductive restriction" (Oxford Research Encyclopedia).

The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

element.label: Description
element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Ames Collection. Letter from Superintendent Z. A. Philips of the Mississippi State Penitentiary to Mississippi Governor Adelbert Ames, informing Ames of the difficulties in incarcerating Susan Stokes, a female convict that is far into a pregnancy. Philips advises that he has no place to put Stokes "out of hearing of the male convicts" during labor.

div.fw: Letter from Superintendent Z. A. Philips to Mississippi Governor Adelbert Ames; August 25, 1869
div.p:
Bvt. Major General A. Ames
Provisional Governor of Miss.

I beg respectfully, to report for your information that a female convict named Susan Stokes was received yesterday from the Sheriff of Lauder-dale County, far advanced in pregnan-cy. She was convicted and sentenced to twelve months imprisonment at the August term of the Circuit Court of that county for Grand Larceny, and has been I understand some time in jail.
This place is not in my opinion, a proper one for a woman to be in during the pains of labor, as we have no place to put them out of hearing of the male convicts.

I am, General
Your obedient Servant

Z. A. Philips,
Supt for Lessee
